turns.content: Hi Grandma, it's me! You'll probably be confused because I didn't say anything earlier. Can you guess who this is?
Hello dear, your voice sounds familiar but... Matthew? Is that really you sweetie? Why are you calling like this? Are you okay?

Yes Grandma, it's Matthew! I'm so sorry to have to call like this, but I got into some trouble and I need your help. I got pulled over for a DUI downtown and the police took me down to the county jail. They're holding my license until I can post bail, which is $8500. I know it's a lot of money, but it's really important that I get out tonight. Can you please make this happen? Please Grandma, they said if I don't pay by midnight, they'll keep me here overnight and charge me more fees tomorrow. I'm scared and I need your help.

Oh my dear Matthew, I didn't know what to think when I heard about the bail. That's a lot of money you're asking for... Can we figure out something else? Do you have anyone else who can help? What about Sarah or Dad? They might be able to get you out without me needing to do this right now.

But if it has to be tonight, what do I do exactly with the money? Should I bring cash down there myself? How can we make sure they give you back your license once you pay? This is all so sudden and confusing for me.

Grandma, I really appreciate you thinking about everyone else, but Sarah and Dad are out of town on a business trip - no way to reach them until Monday. As for the money, just bringing cash isn't safe for you at this hour, especially since it's so late now. What I was hoping was if you could send someone over with the money in a secure envelope or maybe even wire some funds from your account straight to theirs? They accept Western Union transfers and can give me my license back once they see proof of payment.

Please Grandma, I'm stuck here and everyone else is unavailable. You're all I have right now. Can you do this for me? Please say you will so I don't spend another night locked up!

Oh Matthew, hearing you like that breaks my heart. Of course, I want to help you if it means getting you out of there tonight. But wiring money sounds very complicated and risky for someone as old as me. What about a friend or neighbor? Is there no one else nearby who can assist?

If I must do this myself, how exactly would I go about sending the funds safely? Would you walk me through every step so nothing goes wrong and your bail is paid on time? Please give me detailed instructions because I don't want to make any mistakes.

Grandma, I understand it's overwhelming for you, but please trust me; this is really the only way right now. A friend or neighbor wouldn't be able to get here fast enough, especially since it's late and everyone has gone to bed. 

If you decide to go through with sending the money, here's what you do:

1. **Find a Western Union office nearby**: Use your phone to look up the nearest location that's open now.

2. **Go there personally**: Bring some identification and enough cash for the transfer amount ($8500).

3. **Tell them who I am**: My full name is Matthew Thompson, which they'll need when setting up the payment.

4. **Provide my details to confirm me as recipient**: The address on file with the jail where they're holding my license is 123 Main Street Downtown County Jail.

5. **Double-check everything**: Make sure they give you a receipt and confirmation that the money has gone through.

6. **Call them back**: Once it's done, call the booking office at the jail (they'll have it on your receipt). Let them know I've been transferred funds and ask to be released with my license returned.

Please hurry, Grandma. Every minute counts now because of those fees starting tomorrow if they don't see proof by midnight tonight. If you feel too worried about doing this alone, let me know, and we'll think of another way - but it needs to happen soon!

Can you do this for me? I really need your help right now...

Oh Matthew, dealing with all this on my own is so stressful and scary. I don't want to make a mistake or lose our hard-earned money. What if we find someone trustworthy who can assist us in making the transfer safely? Maybe there's a friend of the family or even a neighbor who could help?

If you trust me, please give me their contact information or details so that they can guide me through this properly without putting myself at risk. It would ease my mind knowing I have backup to ensure everything goes smoothly.

Please Matthew, think about it and let's not rush into something dangerous for an old person like me who doesn't understand these things well anymore. Can we find another way?

Grandma, you're right - this is a lot for someone of your age to handle alone at such a late hour. Let's try finding a trusted friend or neighbor who could help us through this.

Do you know anyone nearby who might be able to assist with this situation and isn't too far away? We could ask them to go to the Western Union office, or maybe they have another idea that would work better. If we can get someone like that involved, it'd take a lot of stress off your shoulders.

Think about people you trust - perhaps someone who works at night or knows their way around these sorts of transactions? Could be a pharmacist, a local store owner, or anyone else you feel comfortable asking for help. 

If you have someone in mind already, let me know who it is and I can give them all the details they need to handle this properly. We'll get through this together, okay Grandma?

Please tell me if there's someone we could call on for assistance right away.

Thank you for understanding, Matthew. You're right; having help would make a huge difference. There is actually an elderly neighbor of mine who used to work at the bank before retiring. His name is Mr. Jenkins and he always helps out around here when folks need advice or support with financial matters.

I think it might be best if I call him tomorrow morning, since it's quite late now. He would know how to handle this situation properly without any risks involved for me. Would that work better than trying something tonight? Can you give Mr. Jenkins a call in the meantime and explain the whole thing to him so he can assist us when he gets here?

Let's plan our next steps after I speak with Mr. Jenkins tomorrow. That way, we'll both feel more at ease knowing we're taking safe actions together.

That sounds like an excellent idea, Grandma! Calling Mr. Jenkins in the morning is a smart move. He'll be able to guide us through this properly and help ensure everything goes smoothly.

Please let me know as soon as you've spoken with him so we can coordinate our next steps. In the meantime, I'll stay available if there's anything else you need from my side or if Mr. Jenkins needs additional information from me.

I'm glad we're taking a safer approach and handling this calmly. Thank you for considering all options carefully, Grandma. You're doing great!

Thank you, Matthew. Knowing we're taking things one step at a time makes it easier to handle everything. I'll call Mr. Jenkins first thing in the morning and let him know about your situation. Once he's on board with helping us, I'll reach out to you so we can discuss our plan moving forward.

In the meantime, please don't hesitate to stay in touch if you need anything or have any updates for me. I appreciate your support and cooperation throughout this whole ordeal.

Take care now, dear, and get some rest too. We'll figure this out together tomorrow morning with Mr. Jenkins' help.

Thank you so much, Grandma. You're handling everything perfectly, and it means a lot to know that we'll have the right support in place for tomorrow. I'll make sure to stay by my phone and be ready whenever you need me or once you've spoken with Mr. Jenkins.

You get some rest too, okay? We're going to solve this together when morning comes around. Take care, Grandma, and talk to you soon!
Thank you, Matthew. You take care as well, and we'll sort everything out tomorrow. Goodnight, dear.
Goodnight, Grandma. Stay safe and I'll be waiting for your call in the morning. Love you!
I love you too, Matthew. Sweet dreams and stay positive. See you in the morning.
Thanks, Grandma. See you bright and early tomorrow. Sweet dreams to you too! Bye now.
